learning_outcomes: Recognize and reproduce basic sounds of the Breton alphabet.
Understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases (e.g., greetings, introductions).
Introduce him/herself and others simply (e.g., Me eo... - I am...).
Ask and answer simple questions about personal details (name, origin).
Interact in a very simple way if the other person speaks slowly, clearly, and is prepared to help.
Recognize familiar names, words, and very simple sentences in Breton.

sections.title: ⚙️Petra eo? (What is it?)
grammar_points: Petra eo an dra-mañ? (What is this thing?)
N'eo ket ..., met ... eo. (It is not ..., but it is ...)

language_focus_topics: The Breton Alphabet (Lizherenneg) and pronunciation of letters (including ch, c'h, gn,ilh).
Basic pronunciation rules: Vowel sounds (including nasal vowels likeañ, eñ, iñ, oñ, uñ). Consonant sounds.
Introduction to Consonant Mutations: Basic concept of soft mutation (kemmadurioù meddal) with very common words (e.g., after 'da' - your).
Nouns: Introduction to grammatical gender (masculine/feminine). Singular nouns.
Articles: Definite articles (an, al, ar). Indefinite articles (un, ul, ur).
Pronouns: Personal pronouns (me, te, eñ, hi, ni, c'hwi, int/i).
Verbs: Present tense of 'bezañ' (to be) - basic forms (on, out, eo/zo, omp, oc'h, int).
Verbs: Present tense of 'endevout/kaout' (to have) - basic forms (am eus, az peus, en deus/he deus).
Basic Sentence Structure: Verb-Subject-Object (VSO) tendency for simple sentences. Simple affirmative and negative statements.
Negation: 'ne ... ket' structure around the verb (e.g., Ne glevan ket - I don't hear).
Simple Questions: Intonation. Basic question words (Piv? Petra? Pelec'h? Pegoulz?).
Day 1 Grammar - 'Petra eo?' (What is it?): Petra eo an dra-mañ?, Hag ... eo?, Hag ... eo pe ...?, ... eo., N'eo ket ... ., N'eo ket ..., met ... eo.
vocabulary_topics: Deiz 1: Gerioù Diazez (Day 1: Basic Words): Demat/Salud (hello), Kenavo (goodbye), Ya (yes), Nann (no), Trugarez (thank you), Mann ebet (you're welcome), Mar plij (please), Mat eo (alright/ok), Unan (one), Te (tea), Kafe (coffee), Dour (water), Chug (juice), Bier (beer), Gwin (wine), Arc'hant dizolo (cash), Kartenn (card).
Greetings: Demat, Kenavo, Salud, Mont a ra? Mat an traoù?, Trist eo an amzer.
Introductions & Personal Information: Pe anv out? ... eo ma anv. Plijet bras. Eus pelec'h out? Eus ... on.
Basic responses: Ya, Nann / N'eo ket.
Colors: ruz, glas, gwer, melen, du, gwenn (basic).
Common Objects: levr, taol, kador, ti, karr, pellgomz.
Basic Food & Drink: bara, dour, laezh, kafe, te, kig, pesked.
Classroom language: Adlavarit, mar plij. Ne gomprenan ket.
pronunciation_focus_topics: Mastering sounds of the Breton alphabet, including digraphs (ch, c'h, gn) and trigraph (ilh).
Nasal vowels (an, añ, ein, eñ, eun, euñ, in, iñ, on, oñ, oun, uñ).
The 'zh' sound (often /z/, but /h/ in some dialects).
Word stress (generally penultimate, but can vary, especially with suffixes or in Vannetais dialect).
Basic intonation for statements and simple questions.
listening_comprehension_skills: Recognize familiar Breton words and very basic phrases when spoken slowly and clearly.
Understand simple greetings, introductions, and farewells.
Follow very simple, clearly articulated instructions.
reading_comprehension_skills: Read and identify all letters of the Breton alphabet.
Read and understand familiar names, words, and very simple sentences.
spoken_interaction_skills: Introduce oneself and ask for someone's name.
Ask and answer simple questions about personal information.
spoken_production_skills: Say the letters of the Breton alphabet.
Produce simple isolated phrases (e.g., 'Me eo Yann.', 'Setu ul levr.').
written_interaction_skills: Recognize own name and familiar words when written.
written_production_skills: Write all letters of the Breton alphabet.
Write one's name and other simple familiar words.
Copy familiar words and short sentences.
cultural_competence_topics: Basic awareness of Brittany (Breizh) as a distinct cultural and linguistic region in France.
Importance of the Breton language for cultural identity.
Key Breton symbols (e.g., Gwenn-ha-du flag, triskell - basic awareness).
learning_strategies_suggestions: Practice writing Breton letters and digraphs.
Use flashcards for new vocabulary, noting gender of nouns.
Listen to Breton children's songs or simple audio.
Become aware of initial consonant mutations from the start, even with simple examples.
